the offer.
Saturday night Gov. Forbes,
Mr. Carroll,
Rogers,
Remer,
Dr. Jones,
Chevalier and I
all went
to dinner with the Chiang Kai-sheks.
The dinner
was foreign
style with knives and forks -
very simple and
quite good,
except for one
vicious pink jelly salads.
present in
addition to us were Mr.
Donald,
Liu and General Chiang's
confidential
secretary.
Gov. Forbes
Chiang's right and
on her left.
Carroll sat on the General's right and I sat on
So you see we aviation men received preferred consideration
Your boy friend Chevalier
much to his apparent discomfort
sat between the non-inglish speaking Secretary and
the many-language-
knowing no-language-speaking taciturn Dr. Jones:
"Chevy" couldn't
have been more effectively
muzzled and I
suspect someone must have
off Madam Chiang to
the seating that way.
Chevalier
always insists on all members of
the Mission wearing that ridiculous
red rayon badge
every function and got furious when I refused to
on my dinner coat to
the Chiang's party.
Obviously the only
ever wearing it is for purposes of identification and
it was
out of place at a private dinner.
I urged them
all not to go looking like a delegation of
town Rotarians but
I was the only one without a badge and
caught a faint smile
of approval from Madam
After dinner something very funny happened - Gov. Forbes
General
Chiang for an autographed ploture, whereupon the General
wanted one too
quite naturally
I said that I would like
A secretary
broight a lot of pictures and the General
autographed one for
each member of the party
from Chiang
using the Chinese
characters
on our respective carâs.
the stack and he only had six pictures so he sent
upstairs for another portrait which was much better and considerably
larger - inscribed it
to me and said through Madam Chiang as inter-
preter
"Last and best."
Of course I'm glad to have it but don't know
what on earth to do with it and would rather have had a smaller one.
I wired you this moming early advising you of my plans to
to Manila and will be looking
forward to hearing whether or not
you are all oK.
Got your first letter and
one From Frances at Hankow.
Called up
the MeGleskey/s and invited myself for supper - gave them
your best - also saw the Josslyns at a cocktail party given us by the
Schillings -
Standard 011 No.
1 at Hankow.
Now approaching Shanghai•
Probably
won't write again until we start
for Hongkong tonorrow.
you that Leighton Rogers cabled New York immediately
the accident to put the brakes on the publication of any stories
about his injury.
His office eabled back "Congratulations
tarat pase of every newspaper in Amerioa stop as a publicity stunt
it was a wow exclamation point recommend more conservative methods."
Professor Remer who is a
statistician and who was making his second
flight said that there had been
four accidents on CNAC lines and he
had been in 25% of them also that 50% of his flights had ended in a
crash -
that he had been in 50% of the accidents in which no one
was killed (Geo Rummill & Broiles) •
They have both been
good sports
and that has helped me over a situation
which you can well imagine
has been a most distressing one from many angles.
Lots of love and I'll be looking forward to seeing you when
I come back.
Harold
